node.Title: Improving Diversity with Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs
node.Time: 10:00 to 11:00
node.Short-abstract:
"Diversity" and "inclusion" have become popular buzzwords in the past five years among the tech community. Many open source projects have tried to attract developers who are traditionally underrepresented in tech, but some lack a systematic approach.

In 1943, Maslow defined the human hierarchy of needs: physiological, safety, belonging, esteem, and finally, self-actualization. Maslow theorized that the most urgent needs must be met before a larger goal can be accomplished. This talk will use Maslow's hierarchy of needs to create a systematic approach for increasing diversity in open source.

node.Title: Linux Installfest
node.Time: 10:00 to 17:00
node.Short-abstract: More details to follow soon. RSVP required.

node.Title: HAM Radio Exams
node.Time: 11:00 to 15:00
node.Short-abstract: HAM Radio Exams will be available at SCALE. Â

node.Title: LPI and BSDA Exams
node.Time: 11:00 to 12:30
node.Short-abstract: Linux Professional Institute (LPI) and the BSD Certification Group will be offering certification exams at SCALE 14x. Pre-registration for these exams is required.

node.Title: An Introduction to Container Security
node.Time: 11:30 to 12:30
node.Short-abstract: Red Hat's Thomas Cameron will give a quick overview of container security. He'll discuss Linux capabilities (libcap), Security Enhanced Linux, control groups, kernel namespaces, tips and tricks, and bust soem myths about containers.

node.Title: Come learn about Cloud Foundry, the open source, cloud native platform
node.Time: 11:30 to 12:30
node.Short-abstract: Cloud Foundry is an open source platform to deploy, monitor, recover, scale and update your apps. Come learn about Cloud Foundry,Â  about how itâs developed and see a demo. As an open source software project, itâs developed in the open, by organizations (including SAP, Pivotal, HP, GE, IBM and many others) using methods like pair programming and dojos.

node.Title: A brief introduction to Dart
node.Time: 11:30 to 12:30
node.Short-abstract: Imagine a language with the browser-side and server-side deployability of Javascript, but with a modern syntax, including strong (but optional!) type safety, modern development and debugging facilities, good multithreading, a command-line scripting facility, and a familiar syntax resembling Java. Â You don't have to imagine! Â Dart is here! Randal delivers a brief introduction to Dart, including history, status, and future.

node.Title: Intro to Music Making with GNU/Linux
node.Time: 11:30 to 12:30
node.Short-abstract: Overview of music software basics for GNU/Linux covering JACK, ALSA, hardware issues, Audacity, Musescore, Hyrdrogen, Ardour, plugins, specialized repos and distros, and more.

node.Title: DNSSEC
node.Time: 11:30 to 12:30
node.Short-abstract: DNS (Domain Name System) is an integral part of the Internet, unfortunately it is insecure. DNSSEC is a major upgrade to the security of the Internet. It provides us with authentication of DNS data, data integrity, and authenticated denial of existence. âDNSSec is an absolute requirement if we want to . . . use the Internet for anything non-trivial,â Cricket Liu. I will give an overview of how DNS works and why it is vulnerable, then how DNSSEC addresses these issues. I will discuss the challenges of DNSSEC deployment, but also the additional possibilities it provides, such as DANE.

node.Title: Finding the Value of Community
node.Time: 11:30 to 12:30
node.Short-abstract:
Open source projects have a lot of offer to users, developers, and
community members, but can they add value to businesses?

node.Title: The 7 Rules for Creating World Class Technical Documentation, v.2016
node.Time: 11:30 to 12:30
node.Short-abstract:
Bob Reselman has been presenting the 7 Rules for Creating World Class Technical Documentation to audiences worldwide for close to a decade. This specialÂ Version 2016 pays particular attention to the structured use of diagrams, illustrations and video when creating effective documentation.

You can view the article upon which this talk is based at:Â http://www.developer.com/tech/article.php/3848981/The-7-Rules-for-Writin...

Â

node.Title: Fix the website: A devops success story
node.Time: 11:30 to 12:30
node.Short-abstract:
"the website is too slow!" Â A cry for help. Â But what exactly does it mean?

I'll walk you through my analysis and debugging of a major (comscore top 30) website -- digging through metrics, emotions, facts, lore opinions, and bad statistics. Â And then how I fought to explain and eventually fix the number (If not the real problem).

node.Title: Real-world Big Data workloads in the cloud
node.Time: 11:30 to 12:30
node.Short-abstract: Deploying, configuring, and maintaining a Big Data platform doesn't have to be your full time job. Â Let Juju handle that so you can focus on the fun part -- solving real Big Data problems!

node.Title: What is UX?
node.Time: 11:30 to 12:30
node.Short-abstract: ssidy introduces the idea of User Experience (UX) and tackles common myths as to what âUXâ means. He then dives into why itâs essential to open source projects in the current technology landscape and lastly, offers some practical advice for open source projects seeking to engrain UX into their workflow.

node.Title: From Sys Admin to Netflix SRE
node.Time: 11:30 to 12:30
node.Short-abstract: From Sys Admin to Netflix SRE

node.Title: Teaching Open Source - Education Success Stories
node.Time: 11:30 to 12:30
node.Short-abstract: Most schools do not teach the concepts or methods that we use every day in Free and Open Source Communities, and this is putting students at a distinct disadvantage when entering the technology sector. However, there are some success stories to be proud of. In this session, I'll discuss how some schools are teaching open source today.

node.Title: Using Swagger to tame HTTP/JSON interfaces
node.Time: 13:30 to 14:30
node.Short-abstract: The Swagger project defines an open source language and tooling for specifying and consuming HTTP/JSON interfaces. Â In this talk I describe how we have used this technology at Yelp to retrofit interfaces to our growing ecosystem of HTTP/JSON services.

node.Title: If You Build It, They Won't Come
node.Time: 13:30 to 14:30
node.Short-abstract: Good code isn't enough for a successful open source project. First of all, only you know how to use what you've made. Maybe it's time for Â a little UI and UX help? At the very least some documentation! And that's only the beginning. Ruth Suehle, manager of Red Hat's Open Source and Standards community leadership team, will take you throu hexamples of the best and the worst, from projects large and small, to help you see what you need beyond your code to build a successful open source project and community.

node.Title: Preventing Unauthorized Email Spoofing with DMARC
node.Time: 13:30 to 14:30
node.Short-abstract:
SMTP lacks authentication. This basic oversight has proven a boon for cybercriminals, who leverage email's insecurity to steal billions of dollars every year. In this session you'll learn about DMARC, a standard for email authentication that can prevent unauthorized email spoofing.

After a technical overview of SPF, DKIM, and DMARC we will discuss the open source tools available to help you implement these standards. We'll explore some implementation issues, propose some work-arounds, and end with some adoption statistics.Â

node.Title: Data Lifecycles at Massive Scale Using Python
node.Time: 13:30 to 14:30
node.Short-abstract: FlipboardÂ has hundreds of jobs running in the cloud and that number is continually growing with their increasing user base and feature sets. Qubole and Flipboard will look inside Flipboardâs data lifecycle and how it uses Python, Apache Hive, cloud technologies such as AWS and Qubole, and its own algorithms to ultimately provide content recommendations to its audience. They will delve into the work they are doing with in-memory processing, and how the latest cloud technologies enable Flipboard to manage and analyze large datasets continuously, cost-effectively and at scale.

node.Title: Devopsing the Operating System
node.Time: 13:30 to 14:30
node.Short-abstract: Over the past few years there has been a strong adoption to containerization as a acceptable model for mass compute consumption. Â With this adoption there has been a trend more and more to create single purpose operating systems.Â

node.Title: Cloud 2.0 - How Containers, Microservices and Open Source Software are Redefining Cloud Computing
node.Time: 13:30 to 14:30
node.Short-abstract: This session will outline the evolution of cloud computing from EC2 to OpenStack and the current state of technology and thinking about how to deploy cloud services and what role open source plays in those deployments.Â

node.Title: Seeing Linux Without a Screen
node.Time: 13:30 to 14:30
node.Short-abstract: The question isn't "Can a blind person use a Linux machine?", it should be "How does a blind person use a computer running Linux?". The purpose of this presentation is to show several different applications and subsystems that have been modified in such a way to facilitate the use of a system without looking at the screen and use of keyboard input rather than a mouse.

node.Title: Broken Linux Performance Tools
node.Time: 13:30 to 14:30
node.Short-abstract: Broken benchmarks, misleading metrics, and terrible tools. This talk will help you navigate the treacherous waters of Linux performance tools, touring common problems with system tools, metrics, statistics, visualizations, measurement overhead, and benchmarks. You might discover that tools you have been using for years, are in fact, misleading, dangerous, or broken.

node.Title: We're out of addresses, now what?
node.Time: 13:30 to 14:30
node.Short-abstract: We'll look at the history and process by which we used up 3.2 billion addresses and plans for getting people to a place where they can use another 3.4x10^38 addresses instead.

node.Title: Patterns and Practices for Open Source Project Success
node.Time: 13:30 to 14:30
node.Short-abstract: There are a set of patterns that successful open source software projects follow. These activities can be organized around software construction, community development, and IP management activities. This talk explores their connections to build on ramps for community success.

node.Title: Why you can't find new grads with FOSS experience...
node.Time: 13:30 to 14:30
node.Short-abstract:
Open source is huge. It seems like common sense that university students would learn -- or at least be exposed to -- the way open source works, yet very few are. This session will explore the barriers to âteaching open sourceâ in order to help communities better understand: how university systems tend to work; the current CS curriculum; and the mindset of CS instructors.

Weâll also look at ways that communities can help -- both with programs that currently exist and those that are being developed.

node.Title: HTTP/2 pros and cons. Protocol and use cases overview.
node.Time: 13:30 to 14:30
node.Short-abstract:
At NGINX we have recently included support for HTTP/2 protocol in our web server software. This new protocol has a number of important use cases. We will review:

  • Protocol details
  • Different connection types
  • Use of SSL/TLS and security details
  • Cases when HTTP/2 protocol works great and cases where benefits are minimal.

node.Title: Project Hosting 3.0
node.Time: 15:00 to 16:00
node.Short-abstract: Over the past ten to fifteen years, the landscape of FOSS project hosting has evolved. This session will cover a brief history of FOSS project hosting, explain what advances have been made in the past few years, cover what I feel projects are needing that isnât available and finally discuss what I think FOSS project hosting should look like in the coming years.

node.Title: Offline Linux Educational Servers for Disconnected Communities
node.Time: 15:00 to 16:00
node.Short-abstract: World Possible develops and maintains RACHEL, a Remote Area Community Hotspot for Education and Learning. RACHEL is an infinitely scalable virtual server, or small linux based portable server, that provides key Creative Commons educational resources to developing communities that lack internet access. RACHEL makes available offline versions of Wikipedia, The Khan Academy, CK-12 textbooks, UNESCO Library, Hesperian Health Guides and other educational resources by packaging them on a flash drive.Â

node.Title: Patroni: Your HA Patron Saint
node.Time: 15:00 to 16:00
node.Short-abstract: Patroni is your patron saint of of HA Postgres, permitting you to set-and-forget your replication clusters.Â  Based on Governor from Compose.io, Patroni integrates with Docker or public clouds to help you create an always-on, automated failover PostgreSQL single-master replication cluster.Â  Never be woken up at 3am for a failover again!

node.Title: 4 Years in the Trenches with Linux/QEMU/libvirt
node.Time: 15:00 to 16:00
node.Short-abstract: Over the past 4 years of running production OpenStack clouds for our clients weâve learned a lot about the Linux/QEMU/libvirt stack. In ths session we will talk about our experience deploying and supporting this stack. We will cover a range of topics including how to tune the stack for performance of VMs, functionality of orchestration tasks such as live migration, and for resilience and error handling when the unexpected happens. Finally we will look at strategies for performing in-place upgrades and what type of challenges this can bring.

node.Title: Automation testing with python - Then now and tomorrow
node.Time: 15:00 to 16:00
node.Short-abstract: We know that python is a strong programming language which has an easy learning and a very good syntax. In this presentation I would like to show how python has evolved as a testing tool, and provide an overview for beginners that python can be used for unit testing, integration testing, end to end testing, gui testing, and headless testing.

node.Title: Use More Free Software at Work: How to Approach the Legal Department
node.Time: 15:00 to 16:00
node.Short-abstract: Many companies, schools or projects could benefit tremendously from using free software, but free software enthusiasts and institutional gatekeepers are coming from very different perspectives. Developers tend to be most familiar with FOSS's benefits; reusing code, public code review for bugs, increased project capacity and of course, cost. The legal department has it's own mandate and is often most familiar with the risks, some real and some perceived.

node.Title: Rust: Systems Programming for Web Developers
node.Time: 15:00 to 16:00
node.Short-abstract: The modern web stack is made up of a dozen different systems, but too few people know how to create and support them. I believe this is because systems programming has historically had too many barriers to entry, such as memory safety and the trading of expressiveness for performance. Let us explore some of the ways Rust breaks down these barriers and can make systems programming feel much more approachable to web developers.

node.Title: Penguins all the way up
node.Time: 15:00 to 16:00
node.Short-abstract: A brief history of networking and a look at the present and future. What it is and what it holds for the open-source community.

node.Title: syslog-ng: From Raw Data to Big Data
node.Time: 15:00 to 16:00
node.Short-abstract:
Â 

syslog-ng is an enhanced logging daemon, with a focus on central log collection. It collects logs from many different sources, processes and filters them and forwards them to a destination. This session focuses on how syslog-ng parses important information from incoming messages and how to send this information to âbig dataâ destinations, like HDFS, Kafka, ElasticSearch or MongoDB.

Â

node.Title: Are Today's FOSS Security Practices Robust Enough in the Cloud Era?
node.Time: 15:00 to 16:00
node.Short-abstract: Vulnerabilities like Heartbleed and Shellshock have brought the security practices and track record of open-source projects into the spotlight. We will take closer look at security practices of projects and answer the question: Are open source security practices a fit for the cloud?

node.Title: A fresh look at SELinux...
node.Time: 15:00 to 16:00
node.Short-abstract:
SELinux has been around for a long time, but people are still confused by it.Â  This talk will explain what the technology is doing, in simple terms using the SELinux coloring book.Â 

I will then go on to explain the 4 things SELinux is trying to tell you and how you can modify your machine so the SELinux can be run in enforcing mode and your applications will be able to run more securely.

node.Title: Measuring the health of your Open Source Project: For your Employer, for your Community, and for You
node.Time: 15:00 to 16:00
node.Short-abstract: Unhealthy Open Source projects are doomed to fail. But how do you measure the health of a project? Whether youâre providing analysis for the company or taking a community-driven approach, you need methods, metrics, tactics to provide a clear picture of your projectâs data. Duane OâBrien (Open Source Programs, PayPal) and Eva Gantz (Global Community, Stellar.org) will look at measuring project health through the lenses of both corporate sponsor and community cultivator. Duane and Eva will share cross-industry tools, providing specific recommendations for strategies to try and to avoid.

node.Title: Creating a third wave of free/open source software
node.Time: 16:30 to 17:30
node.Short-abstract: Over the last 20 years, the open source software movement has gone from being an upstart competitor to proprietary business, to a core component of our largest business and infrastructure systems. We made it! So why are we so burned out, and why does our contributor base still not reflect the wide range of users? I'll break down some key elements that indicate we're at the start of the third wave of FOSS, starting with software freedoms, moving through OSI-approved licensing, to the challenges we face today.

node.Title: Building IoT Architectures with MongoDB
node.Time: 16:30 to 17:30
node.Short-abstract: The Internet of Things (IoT) concerns data drawn from a great number of devices, including sensors, embedded systems and wearable devices.Â

node.Title: Anatomy of the Command Line
node.Time: 16:30 to 17:30
node.Short-abstract:
Order matters when bash executes a command, but isn't strictly left to right. Redirects, functions, sub-shells, {brace,tilde,parameter,variable,arithmetic} expansion, pipes, globbing, regular expressions, command substitution and more.

What happens when and how does it affect other portions of the command? Which portions of the command line are evaluated by the shell and which aren't?

node.Title: Yes, the FCC Might Ban Your Operating System
node.Time: 16:30 to 17:30
node.Short-abstract: What could possibly make thousands of FLOSS advocates, ham radio operators, researchers and physicians stand together? One obscure FCC rulemaking proposal on wireless radios. Eric Schultz, one of the leaders of the Save Wifi Initiative, discusses the details of the extreme proposals of FCC. You'll learn the history of regulators quietly locking down wireless radios and how it's unintentionally extending to a lockdown of the operating systems of devices.

node.Title: "adapt install [anything]" on your Ubuntu LTS server/desktop!
node.Time: 16:30 to 17:30
node.Short-abstract: The numbers don't lie. 97% of the Ubuntu servers running in the public cloud are Ubuntu LTS versions -- 12.04 or 14.04, and 16.04 is rapidly approaching. Ubuntu desktops numbers are similar, in the 90%+ range as well. We often find ourselves, however, on an LTS desktop and server needing just one or two packages from a newer Ubuntu release. I'm pleased to introduce the 'adapt' utility which provides exactly that capability, by combining the goodness from apt-get and Linux Containers with LXD!

node.Title: Introduction to MidoNet Plugin for OpenStack Neutron
node.Time: 16:30 to 17:30
node.Short-abstract: MidoNet is a production-grade network virtualization software that is fully integrated with OpenStack to provide a fully fault-tolerant, scale-out network for public or private clouds. Replacing the default plug-in in Neutron, MidoNet can be used and controlled through the Horizon web UI and the Neutron CLI.

node.Title: Education Design 2.0
node.Time: 16:30 to 17:30
node.Short-abstract: The rapid advancements of new technologies have positive implications for teaching and learning with access to extensive information, platforms for communication & collaboration, and tools for critical thinking & creativity. This is a talk on how Tinkercad, an open source 3D CAD tool, can be used to explore and visualize real-world concepts to improve student achievement in K-12 education. She will discuss her latest research in educational technology and the need to provide relevant transformative learning experiences in preparation for college and career.

node.Title: ScyllaDB: Cassandra compatibility at 1.8 million requests per node
node.Time: 16:30 to 17:30
node.Short-abstract: Scylla is a new NoSQL database, capable of 2 million requests per second per node with Apache Cassandra compatibility. Scylla enables faster cluster scaling and more overhead to handle complex queries.

node.Title: KVM Weather Report
node.Time: 16:30 to 17:30
node.Short-abstract: When users run a KVM virtual machine, they see a seamless experienceÂ of a guest OS running on top of the host Linux OS.Â

node.Title: The Road To Mordor: Information Security Issues and Your Open Source Project
node.Time: 16:30 to 17:30
node.Short-abstract: From time to time, communities will run across information security incidents. In the course of project expansion, it always seems like a good idea to wake up a new instance of Something_With_A_Database and not write down the credentials or think very clearly about what the permissions are on that new instance. If you're involved in open source for any length of time, you're going to discover a hack at some point in time. It turns out that the story of the Lord of the Rings is a great model for being able to deal with your information security issues.

node.Title: Terrible Ideas in Git
node.Time: 16:30 to 17:30
node.Short-abstract: dapted from his class "The Screaming Horrors of Git," Corey takes us on a magical tour through the (mis)use of Git to do things itsÂ creators never intended. In this humorously delivered exploration of one of the open source community's more ubiquitous tools, Corey demonstrates that a finely crafted wrench makes a barely acceptable hammer if you hold it wrong.

node.Title: A Security State of Mind: Compliance and Vulnerability Audits for Containers
node.Time: 16:30 to 17:30
node.Short-abstract:
Join Chris Van Tuin, Chief Technologist, West at Red Hat, as he walks through how OpenSCAP can help protect and secure the business.

Â
